body.p: Which of the following does not affect the amount of hormone circulating at one time?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The rate of hormone production will affect the amount in circulation.
Correct. Target cells are always present in the body. The number of receptors on them may decrease the hormone circulating.
Incorrect. The rate of blood flow to carry the hormones to their targets will affect the amount circulating.
Incorrect. How much of a hormone is secreted from an endocrine gland will affect the amount in circulation

body.p: Which of the following hormones is not derived from cholesterol?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The precursor of estrogen is cholesterol.
Incorrect. The precursor of cortisol is cholesterol.
Incorrect. The precursor of aldosterone is cholesterol.
Correct. The precursor of prostaglandins is polyunsaturated fatty acids.

body.p: Why do steroid hormones have a longer half-life than other hormones?

input.choice: Because they are bound to carriers
Because they are released from the adrenal gland
Because they are excreted in urine or bile

feedback.p: Correct. Because they are water insoluble they must be with a transport protein to be carried in the blood. This results in them circulating longer.
Incorrect. The adrenal gland does secrete cortisol which is an example of this type of hormone.
Incorrect. Many steroid derived hormones are derived from cholesterol but they are chemically unique.
Incorrect. Steroid hormones are excreted in the bile or urine but this is not the reason they have a long half-life.

body.p: Epinephrine is a derived from of what type of hormone?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Although many amino acid derived hormones come from tryptophane epinephrine does not.
Correct. Epinephrine is derived from tyrosine.
Incorrect. Serine is an amino acid but it is not a precursor for these amino acid hormones.
Incorrect. Proline is an amino acid but it is not a precursor for these amino acid hormones.

body.p: Most peptide hormones are easily transported in the blood plasma because:

feedback.p: Incorrect. Peptide hormones are made of amino acids not lipids.
Correct. The blood plasma is mostly water and these peptide hormones are water soluble.
Incorrect. Some of them have transport proteins but most of them do not need them.
Incorrect. Some of them are large glycoproteins.

body.p: Which of the following is a large glycoprotein?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Oxytocin is a short polypeptide chain.
Incorrect. Antidiuretic hormone is a short polypeptide chain.
Incorrect. Epinephrine is an amino acid hormone.
Correct. Follicle-stimulating hormone is a large glycoprotein.

body.p: What hormone is involved in the positive feedback cycle of child birth?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Insulin is involved in the negative feedback cycle of glucose.
Incorrect. Antidiuretic hormone is involved in the negative feedback cycle of water balance.
Correct. Oxytocin is involved in the positive feedback cycle of child birth.
Incorrect. T 3 is one of the thyroid hormones involved in metabolism.

body.p: Which of the following is a mechanism of stimulating hormone release?

input.choice: All of the above are mechanisms of stimulating hormone release

feedback.p: Partially correct. Humoral regulation is not the only way to stimulate hormone release.
Partially correct. Hormonal regulation is not the only way to stimulate hormone release.
Partially correct. Neural regulation is not the only way to stimulate hormone release.
Correct. All of these are mechanisms of stimulating hormone release.

body.p: Which of the following hormones are controlled by a humoral stimuli?

feedback.p: Incorrect. T 3 is under tropic hormonal stimuli.
Incorrect. Epinephrine is under neural stimuli.
Correct. Insulin is under humoral stimuli of glucose levels in the blood.
Incorrect. Norepinephrine is under neural stimuli.

body.p: What best describes the process of up-regulation?

input.choice: Decrease the number of surface receptors.
Increase the number of surface receptors.

feedback.p: Incorrect. A decrease in the number of receptors is down-regulation.
Incorrect. A decrease in the amount of a hormone will not decrease the activity and is not part of up-regulation.
Correct. The increase in the amount of receptors will result in up-regulation and increased sensitivity.
Incorrect. An increase in the amount of hormone will result in an increase of activity until all of the receptors are occupied.

body.p: Hormones must bind to receptors on target cells to affect changes. Where can these receptors be located?

input.choice: Both B and C are correct

feedback.p: Incorrect. Animal cells do not have cell walls.
Incorrect. This is only one place they can be located.
Incorrect. This is only one place they can be located.
Correct. These receptors can be found both inside the cell and on the plasma membrane.

body.p: What sequence describes how a steroid hormone impacts gene expression?

input.choice: Steroid hormone binds with a plasma membrane receptor, then crosses the plasma membrane, then binds to DNA and regulates transcription.
Steroid hormone crosses the plasma membrane, binds DNA and regulates transcription.
Steroid hormone crosses the plasma membrane, binds to an intracellular hormone receptor in the nucleus, then regulates transcription.
Steroid hormone crosses the plasma membrane, binds to an intracellular hormone receptor in the cytoplasm, the receptor hormone complex then binds to DNA and regulates transcription.

feedback.p: Incorrect. A steroid hormone does not bind to a plasma membrane receptor, it binds to a cytoplasmic receptor.
Incorrect. A steroid hormone must bind with a receptor in the cytoplasm before this complex can bind to the DNA.
Incorrect. A steroid hormone must bind to the receptor complex in the cytoplasm before entering the nucleus.
Correct. A steroid hormone must form a complex with a receptor protein before binding to the DNA and regulating transcription.

body.p: How do peptide hormones affect a target cellâ€™s transcription?

input.choice: They enter the cell and bind with a receptor in the cytoplasm then bind to the DNA.
They enter the cell and bind with a receptor in the nucleus on the DNA.
They bind to the plasma membrane get taken inside and bind to the DNA.
They bind to the receptor on the plasma membrane and initiate a signaling pathway that regulates transcriptions.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Peptide hormones indirectly affect the DNA they do not actually bind to the DNA.
Incorrect. Peptide hormones do not complex with a receptor in the nucleus.
Incorrect. Peptide hormones indirectly affect transcription, they never bind with DNA.
Correct. Peptide hormones indirectly affect transcription, they never bind with the DNA.

body.p: What is the benefit of a G-protein signalling cascade?

input.choice: It allows the signal to be transmitted to the nucleus faster.
It allows the signal from the original signalling molecule to be amplified.
It allows the peptide hormone to enter the cell.

feedback.p: Incorrect. The signal has to go through several primary and secondary messengers, which does not speed up the transmission.
Correct. A single signal molecule can start a cascade that amplifies the original signal many times.
Incorrect. The cascade is a result of the peptide hormone binding the plasma membrane receptor.
Incorrect. This signal pathway requires energy from the cell.

body.p: Which hormone is not secreted by the anterior pituitary gland?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Adrenocorotictropic hormone is secreted by the anterior pituitary.
Incorrect. Growth hormone is secreted by the anterior pituitary.
Correct. Antidiuretic hormone is released from the posterior pituitary.
Incorrect. Prolactin is released by the anterior pituitary.

body.p: Why are many of the hormones released by the hypothalamus and pituitary gland called tropic hormones?

input.choice: They are located in the brain and are closely connected to the nervous system.
They are produced by neurosecretory cells.
They are hormones that control the release of another hormone.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Although many of these hormones are involved in growth and developmen,t that is not why they are called tropic. Many of these hormones are called trophic.
Incorrect. These hormones are categorized as tropic because of their function not their location.
Incorrect. These hormones are categorized as tropic because of their function not because of how they are secreted.
Correct. Tropic hormones control the release of other hormones. The pituitary gland is sometimes called the master gland because it releases these horomones.

body.p: Which of the following hormones is not secreted by the anterior pituitary?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Growth hormone is secreted by the anterior pituitary.
Correct. Oxytocin is released by the posterior pituitary.
Incorrect. Prolactin is secreted by the anterior pituitary.
Incorrect. Luteinizing hormone is secreted by the anterior pituitary.

body.p: What hormones are considered to be posterior pituitary hormones?

feedback.p: Incorrect. ADH is a posterior pituitary hormone, and prolactin is an anterior pituitary hormone.
Incorrect. ACTH is an anterior pituitary hormone and oxytocin is a posterior pituitary hormone.
Incorrect. ACTH is an anterior pituitary hormone and ADH is a posterior pituitary hormone.
Correct. ADH is a posterior pituitary hormone and oxytocin is a posterior pituitary hormone.

body.p: What is the precursor of the thyroid hormones?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Hemoglobin is found in red blood cells and transports oxygen.
Incorrect. Myoglobin is found in muscle cells and stores oxygen.
Correct. Thyroglobulin is a glycoprotein that is the precursor for the thyroid hormones.
Incorrect. Colloid is the fluid in the follicles that contains the precursor.

body.p: What inorganic molecule is required for the synthesis of the thyroid hormones?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Iron is required for oxygen transport.
Incorrect. Calcium is needed for strong bones and muscle contractions.
Incorrect. Phosphorous is needed for cellular energy.
Correct. Thyroxine has 4 iodine atoms and triiodothyronine has 3 iodine atoms.

body.p: Calcitonin can lower blood calcium by:

input.choice: increasing calcium absorption by the intestine
decreasing the amount of calcium in the urine

feedback.p: Incorrect. Calcitonin decreases the reabsorption so more calcium is released in the urine.
Correct. Calcitonin inhibits bones being broken down and putting more calcium in the blood.
Incorrect. Caclcitonin descreases calcium absorption by the small intestine to prevent more calcium from entering the blood.
Incorrect. Calcitonin decreases tubular reabsorption which results in I more calcium in the urine.

body.p: Parathyroid hormone (PTH) increases the blood calcium concentrations by:

input.choice: stimulating reabsoprtion of calcium in the kidneys
decreasing absorption from the small intestine

feedback.p: Correct. By increasing the amount of calcium reabsorbed from the urine it increases the blood calcium concentration.
Incorrect. PTH increases absorption of calcium from the small intestine so more calcium will enter the blood.
Incorrect. PTH increases the activity of osteoclasts to break down bone and increase calcium concentration in the blood.
Incorrect. PHT may indirectly decrease osteoblast activity to keep calcium from being taken from the blood to build bone.

body.p: Where is the adrenal gland located in the body?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Lateral would mean to the side of the kidney relative to the body.
Incorrect. Medial would mean to the center of the body relative to the kidney.
Incorrect. Inferior to the kidney would be underneath the kidney.
Correct. Superior means on top of or above the kidney. The adrenal glands sit on top of the kidneys.

body.p: What is the function of aldosterone?

input.choice: Regulate fatty acid release from the adipose tissue.
Regulate the release of glucose from the liver.
Regulate the concentration of sodium ions in the urine.

feedback.p: Incorrect. The glucocorticoids stimulate fatty acid release.
Incorrect. The glucocorticoids are involved in creating glucose.
Correct. Aldosterone regulates the concentration of sodium ions in urine.
Incorrect. Androgens affect the sexual characteristics.

body.p: Which of the following is not a function of epinephrine and norepinephrine?

input.choice: Accelerates fat storage in adipose tissues.

feedback.p: Incorrect. These hormones do increase heart rate.
Incorrect. These hormones do increase breathing rate.
Incorrect. These hormones increase the breakdown of glucose for use.
Correct. These hormones increase the breakdown of fats for energy not the storage of fats.

body.p: Melatonin can have what effect on the body?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Melatonin does not have an effect on heart rate.
Correct. High melatonin levels at night make a body sleepy.
Incorrect. Adrenal hormones can give a burst of energy, high levels of melatonin can result in sleepiness.
Incorrect. Melatonin does not result in dizziness.

body.p: Which of the following describes the action of insulin?

input.choice: Insulin will raise blood glucose levels.
Insulin will lower blood glucose levels.
Insulin will increase blood calcium levels.
Insulin will lower blood calcium levels.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Insulin will be released when blood glucose levels are high but it does not increase the blood levels.
Correct. Insulin will lower the blood glucose levels.
Incorrect. PTH will lower blood calcium levels.
Incorrect. Calcitonin will lower blood calcium levels.

body.p: Which of the following is not a function of estrogen?

input.choice: Stimulates the development of female secondary sex characteristics
Softens pubic symphysis to facilitate birthing

feedback.p: Incorrect. Estrogen is involved in the development of female secondary sex characteristics.
Correct. Estrogen does help prepare the body for birth but relaxin specifically affects the pubic symphysis.
Incorrect. Estrogen does play a role in regulating the menstrual cycle.
Incorrect. Estrogen does help maintain the pregnancy.

body.p: Which of the following hormones has a tropic effect?

feedback.p: Incorrect. PTH increases blood calcium levels. This is not an example of a hormone regulating another hormone.
Correct. ACTH stimulates hormone release by the adrenal cortex. A hormone that regulates the release of another hormone is a tropic hormone.
Incorrect. Prolactin promotes milk production. This is not an example of a hormone regulating another hormone.
Incorrect. Antidiuretic hormone stimulates water reabsorption by the kidneys. This is not an example of a hormone regulating another hormone.

body.p: Which of the following is not produced by the endocrine glands of the digestive tract?

feedback.p: Correct. Renin is produced by the kidneys.
Incorrect. Gastrin is produced by the digestive tract.
Incorrect. Secretin is produced by the digestive tract.
Incorrect. CCK is produced by the digestive tract.
